title: My Neighbors Never Go Outside [Part 1]
body:
Funny what you notice, when you’ve got as much free time as I do. I noticed absence of the moldy “For Sale” sign in the neighboring yard right away. They didn’t chain a “SOLD” announcement to the bottom. No, they ripped it right up out of the ground. They left a ragged, black hole in the grass where the post used to be. They were serious about it, it seems.

I guess that’s been a couple years ago, now.

Not long ago, it occurred to me that I never saw a moving truck, after that. I never saw a car in the driveway. I never saw the neighbors come outside. I saw them through the windows, though, only at night. Grey shadows dancing across the blinds.

I wasn’t trying to be nosy. I wasn’t prying. I just noticed, that’s all.

“I wonder what kind of lighting they got over there,” I said. I was raking dinner scraps into the garbage disposal and gazing out of the kitchen window. My husband, George, was sitting at the dinner table, picking his teeth.

“Who?”

“The neighbors. The light in the windows is bluish.”

George squinted at the window. “Probably got a big screen,” he said, sinking back into his chair and examining something at the end of the toothpick. “We should get a big screen.”

“Big screen in every room. Sure,” I said.

“Why not?” George said.

After that, I guess I did get a bit nosy. I mean, who doesn’t ever come out of their house like that?

So, I started really watching. For at least a month now, I’ve kept a close eye on the place. Nothing. It made me uneasy. Nobody else in the neighborhood ever mentioned it, which made me feel a little crazy. Maybe I am, because I started thinking about going over there and knocking on the door. I’d introduce myself to my normal neighbors who must have a perfectly reasonable explanation for never showing their faces outdoors. Then, I could stop thinking about it. Then, I could stop peeking out of the windows.

So, I did it. Yesterday afternoon, while George was at the office, I went over and knocked on the door. As I made my way up the front walk, I thought, I wouldn’t have to ask where the bathroom is. This one’s just like Becky’s down the street. Cookie-cutters, they call them. I knocked and straightened my skirt. I heard a mechanical hum just above me. I turned just as the little camera mounted under the eave focused in on me. Lots of people have security cameras. I don’t, but lots of people do. Sure. As George would say, “Why not?”

I smiled and gave a little wave at the lens. The camera only stared until my smile faded. I cleared my throat and knocked again. I didn’t look at the camera, this time.

If it wasn’t for that camera, I think I would have pressed my ear against the door. I could hear something in there. The murmur of many voices. Maybe they do have a big screen in every room.

Well, nobody answered, and I got tired of staring at the door. The camera whirred again as I turned to leave.

Later that evening, I was slicing vegetables for dinner and frowning at the window looking out on the neighbor’s house, when somebody knocked on my door. I wiped my hands and ran on tiptoe to the front door.

I peered through the peephole. Jennifer.

I sighed and opened the door, “Hey, Jenny,” I said.

“Just Jennifer, Mrs. B!” She always says that, but I can’t help abbreviating her name. Jennifer. It feels too old and clunky for her.

“Hey, Mom said to ask if I could sit with you while she runs to the store!”

I looked over her shoulder to see her aging mother waving from their yard. I smiled and nodded in her direction as I ushered Jennifer inside.

She bounded down the hallway toward the kitchen.

I love Jennifer, but I don’t think I’ll ever get used to seeing a grown woman move that way. The way her mother put it, her brain stopped growing at the age of ten but the rest of her didn’t have any trouble.

“You’re cooking!” she sang as she went.

“Yep! Just getting started. How did you know that?” I called after her.

“Just did,” she said as I slipped through the kitchen door. I believe it. The girl is spooky sometimes.

“So, while I’m cooking, would you like to play a game on my phone?”

“Heck, yeah!” She beamed, clapping her hands.

“Okay,” I said, as I unlocked the screen, “I just found this new one I think you’ll like…”

Then, I noticed that her gaze had wandered to the window looking out at the neighbor’s house. Her jaw went slack. She rubbed the back of her neck, her patent nervous gesture.

“Mrs. B,” she said, frowning, “Did you go see the neighbors? Those neighbors.”

“Well… I…”

“Mrs. B don’t do that anymore!” She whispered, face inches from mine, eyes wide. “They’re bad.”

“Why do you say that, honey?”

“Promise you won’t!”

“Okay, I promise… but why do you think the neighbors are bad?”

She frowned and shook her head rapidly back and forth. Sometimes, when she couldn’t muster the vocabulary to say the thing she desperately wanted to say, she got frustrated. I felt bad. I shouldn’t have asked her like that. She doesn’t know how she knows. She just knows. I put my arm around her shoulder and drew her to me. “Sshh, now. It’s okay.”

She hugged me fiercely while I whispered assurances. Then, it was like it never happened, for Jenny, at least.

It was still on my mind, long after she left. I pushed my dinner around on my plate, while George shoveled his into his mouth.

“Do anything special today?” he asked between mouthfuls.

I forced my eyes away from the window. “Nope. Just, you know, the usual. Jenny came over.”

“Just Jennifer,” George said.

“I know.” I debated telling him what Jennifer said about the neighbors but decided against it. He’d scold me for being nosy.

Later, I laid awake listening to George snore. Jenny’s voice echoed in my head.

They’re bad.

Promise you won’t!

The clock on my nightstand read 2:24 when I slowly swung my legs out of bed a tip-toed to the front door. My bare feet were slick with dew as I climbed the steps to the neighbor's front porch.

The camera whirred and whined as its glass eye focused on me, again. The windows were lit with that eerie, blue light.

I looked over my shoulders at the dead, silent street. I raised my hand to knock, then dropped it, again. I could hear it, the same incessant chorus of whispers.

They’re bad.

Promise!

I jumped the steps and ran through the wet grass back to my house. Back to safety.

Back in bed, as my heart rate slowed to normal, I felt silly. They’re just people. I got spooked because of the quiet and the dark. That’s all. Those whispering voices sound creepy at night... but it's probably just the television.

I think that I’ll pay another visit tomorrow, while George is at work.

They can’t ignore me forever.
